title: 105_hr3915
content: The "Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 1998" allows for the adjustment of status of certain Liberian nationals. The "Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 1998" allows for the adjustment of status to permanent residence for eligible aliens before April 1, 2000, with exceptions to certain grounds of inadmissibility. Alien present in the US under certain orders may apply for adjustment of status without needing to file a motion to reopen, reconsider, or vacate the order. If the application is granted, the order will be canceled; if denied, the order remains effective. Aliens eligible for adjustment of status must be nationals of Liberia and have been granted temporary protected status on or after March 27, 1991. The Attorney General can provide a stay of removal for aliens with a final deportation order if they file an application under subsection (a). Aliens in exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings can apply for adjustment of status under subsection (a) as a defense, with work authorization possible during the application process. If the application is pending for over 180 days without denial, the Attorney General must authorize employment. Adjustment of Status for Spouses and Children: The Attorney General can adjust the status of a Liberian national's spouse, child, or unmarried son/daughter to that of a lawful permanent resident, with specific requirements for physical presence in the United States. The Attorney General can adjust the status of a Liberian national's spouse, child, or unmarried son/daughter to that of a lawful permanent resident if the alien applies for adjustment, is physically present in the US when the application is filed, is eligible for an immigration visa, and is admissible for permanent residence. Exclusion grounds specified in certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act do not apply. Continuous physical presence must be maintained. The Attorney General provides administrative review for adjustment of status applicants, with final determinations not subject to judicial review. No reduction in available visas for aliens. (g) No reduction in available visas when alien granted permanent residence. Secretary of State not required to decrease immigrant visa numbers. (h) Immigration and Nationality Act definitions apply, Attorney General's authority not affected. Eligible aliens may be granted lawful admission status. The alien's eligibility for lawful permanent residence under this section does not prevent them from seeking such status under other applicable laws.
